title-group.article-title: Executive deficits in early onset bipolar disorder versus ADHD: Impact of processing speed and lifetime psychosis

author-notes.corresp: Anne Helseth Udal, Sørlandet Hospital, Postbox 783 Stoa, Arendal 4809, Norway. Email: anne.udal@sshf.no

abstract.p: Executive deficits are reported in both early onset bipolar disorder (BD) and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and controversies regarding comorbidity and symptom overlap have complicated the research on executive function in BD. Reports of the negative impact of executive difficulties on academic functioning indicate a need for a greater focus on executive difficulties in early onset psychiatric disorders. Executive function and processing speed in youths with BD (n = 4), ADHD (n = 26) and BD + ADHD (n = 13) were compared with controls (n = 69). All clinical groups demonstrated executive impairment. The combined group was most impaired. There were no significant differences between the groups. Executive deficit in the BD group was associated with a history of psychotic symptoms. The BD-nonpsychotic group was impaired only with regard to processing speed. Processing speed adjustment improved working memory and normalized interference control in both BD and ADHD. Conclusion: executive deficits in BD may be determined by a history of psychotic symptoms rather than by comorbid ADHD. Some aspects of executive problems appear speed-related.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hypomania and mania in bipolar disorder (BD) share symptoms (distractibility, excessive talking, increased activity, and impulsivity) with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), perhaps due to some shared cognitive deficits. Though mood symptoms are specific to the BD diagnostic criteria, mood instability is a commonly associated feature of ADHD (Skirrow, McLoughlin, Kuntsi, & Asherson, 2009). The specific episodic course of BD may also be difficult to discern in early onset BD, which generally has a more chronic course and more cognitive problems compared with later onset BD (Birmaher & Axelson, 2006), probably caused by immature prefrontal circuitries for affect regulation and cognitive control. Prefrontal brain regions sub-serving cognitive and behaviour control (executive functions) undergo substantial development during late childhood and adolescence. Developmental disturbances in these regions are probably implicated in both ADHD and BD (Marsh, Gerber, & Peterson, 2008), consistent with the executive difficulties described in both disorders (Walshaw, Alloy, & Sabb, 2010). Executive function has been defined as ‘the ability to maintain an appropriate problem set for attaining future goals’ (Welsh & Pennington, 1988) and are often separated into cognitive flexibility, working memory and inhibition (Miyake et al., 2000). Associations between executive deficits and academic impairment are reported in both BD and ADHD (Biederman et al., 2004, 2011).

Controversies regarding the differential diagnosis between BD and ADHD have complicated research on executive functions in BD (Youngstrom, Arnold, & Frazier, 2010), and very few studies have examined cognitive function in BD without ADHD. A direct comparison of these two groups may reveal differences in executive function that could assist in their differentiation. In this context, it is interesting that cognitive dysfunction in BD may be associated with a history of psychotic symptoms (Savitz, van der Merwe, Stein, Solms, & Ramesar, 2009; Simonsen et al., 2011) and a very high prevalence of psychotic mood episodes is reported in early-onset BD (Geller, Tillman, Bolhofner, & Zimerman, 2008; Pavuluri, Herbener, & Sweeney, 2004). Also, some aspects of executive dysfunction in BD may be related to processing speed (Antila, Kieseppa, Partonen, Lonnqvist, & Tuulio-Henriksson, 2011).

In the present study, we compared executive function and processing speed in youths grouped as pure BD (with and without a history of psychotic symptoms), pure ADHD, comorbid BD and ADHD and controls. We hypothesized that the BD group would show executive difficulties slightly different from and independently of comorbid ADHD, and also that executive deficits would be most pronounced in BD with a history of psychotic symptoms. We expected impaired processing speed in all clinical groups. The executive difficulties would, to some degree, be indirectly caused by impaired processing speed.

sec.title: Clinical participants
sec.p: Clinical participants were recruited from a general out-patient child and adolescent psychiatry unit in Norway from December 2004 to January 2009; 1983 individuals were referred to the unit during this period. Whenever BD was suspected (n = 232) by any of the staff, the patient was evaluated for further assessment. Of these, 55 participants were included (ADHD: n = 15; BD: n = 19; BD + ADHD: n = 12). In addition, 17 patients were referred from other units as potential study participants; of these, six were included (BD: n = 5; BD + ADHD: n = 1). Eighteen additional patients with suspected ADHD were selected from other referred patients to optimize age and gender matching; of these 11 ADHD participants were included. The remaining assessed patients did not meet the inclusion criteria (n = 192), met the exclusion criteria (n = 4), did not cooperate due to manic episode (n = 2) or did not wish to participate (n = 6).

sec.title: Inclusion criteria
sec.p: Inclusion criteria were as follows: aged 6–19 years and fulfilled the DSM–IV criteria (American Psychiatric Association, 2000) for either BD, ADHD, ADHD or both.

BD was categorized as BD–I (DSM–IV 296–7), BD–II (DSM–IV 296.89) or BD–NOS. BD–NOS was defined according to the Course of Bipolar Youth Study criteria:
‘A distinct period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood plus the following: (1) 2 DSM–IV manic symptoms (3 if the mood is irritability only) that were clearly associated with the onset of abnormal mood, (2) a clear change in functioning, (3) mood and symptom duration of a minimum of 4 hours within a 24-hour period for a day to be considered meeting the diagnostic threshold and (4) a minimum of 4 days (not necessarily consecutive) meeting the mood, symptom, duration, and functional change criteria over the subject’s lifetime, which could be two 2-day episodes, four 1-day episodes, or another variation’ (Axelson et al., 2006; Birmaher et al., 2006).
Five-year follow-ups revealed that diagnostic conversion to BD–I or BDP–II occurred in 45% of those with BD–NOS (Axelson et al., 2011).
ADHD was defined as ADHD combined type (ADHD–C; DSM–IV 314).

sec.title: Exclusion criteria
sec.p: Exclusion criteria were mental retardation according to DSM–IV and brain injury.

sec.title: Diagnostic assessment
sec.p: The participants and their primary caretaker were assessed by a semi-structured interview based on the Schedule for Affective Disorders and Schizophrenia for School-Age Children – Present and Lifetime Version (KSADS–PL) (Kaufman et al., 1997). All interviews were administered by a trained psychiatrist (first author). The KSADS–PL includes an unstructured interview that reviews lifetime history and course of symptoms, and a semi-structured diagnosis-specific interview with impairment ratings to facilitate the determination of caseness. The taped interviews, supplied with condensed medical history, were validated by a child and adolescent psychiatrist. Inter-rater agreement (kappa) was 1 on BD and 0.87 on ADHD–C. Further information was obtained from each child’s school (via information from the teacher and in-class observation by a clinician). Information regarding lifetime comorbidities, symptoms and reading/language problems was based on information from the KSADS–PL. The final diagnosis was based on the KSADS–PL interview and all available clinical information in a discussion with the main researcher (first author) and an experienced child psychiatrist (last author).

sec.title: Assessment of psychotic symptoms
sec.p: Lifetime presence or absence of psychotic symptoms was also assessed by the diagnostic interview. A history of state-dependent psychotic symptoms was defined as the presence of at least one symptom of hallucination or delusion during a manic or a depressive episode. A history of state-dependent psychotic symptoms was reported in 10 BD patients (hereafter named the BD-psychosis group). The BD-psychosis group was significantly older and reported more comorbid drug abuse compared with the BD group with no history of psychosis (hereafter named the BD-nonpsychosis group). The strikingly high degree of psychotic symptoms in our BD sample may reflect the number of seriously ill BD patients in our sample who were referred from various child and adolescent outpatient units, and also the fact that the psychotic symptoms were reported retrospectively, so that drug related psychotic symptoms and false perceptions may have been interpreted as psychotic mood episodes.

sec.title: Medication, stress and mood symptoms
sec.p: When possible, initiation of medication was delayed until after the diagnostic and neuropsychological assessment. Otherwise, medication was discontinued for a minimum of five times the elimination half-life before neuropsychological assessment, except for mood stabilizers in five patients (one lithium, two lamotrigine, one valproate, one valproate + aripiprazole), although these were not taken on the test day.

Serum-cortisol was measured on the morning of the test day because it can affect test performance (Lee, Shin, & Stein, 2010). The neuropsychologist reported hypomanic and depressive symptoms according to the following scale: (1) no mood symptoms, (2) some mood symptoms, (3) mood symptoms affecting the validity of the results. Some mood symptoms that probably did not affect the validity of the results were reported in one ADHD–C patient and in seven BD patients.

sec.title: Control participants: Typical children
sec.p: Sixty-nine controls were recruited from three secondary schools and one junior high school. All controls attended regular school classes with normal grade levels and had no known learning problems or psychiatric disorders. Exclusion criteria in the control group were evidence of organic brain disease or any head injury with resulting unconsciousness. The parents were asked to confirm that the control children were not using medication, were not receiving treatment from child and adolescent psychiatric services, had not been diagnosed with a learning disability and were not currently receiving any form of special tutoring or education. Controls were not assessed by a diagnostic interview, but the teachers and parents completed report questionnaires from the Achenbach System of Empirically Based Assessment (ASEBA). ASEBA provides T-scores on Syndrome scales and DSM–IV oriented scales scored from the same assessment instruments and normed on the same national samples (Achenbach, Dumenci, & Rescorla, 2003). A T-score greater than 60 reveals evidence of a problem. On DSM–IV oriented subscales, affective problems were reported in seven children by parents and in three children by teachers, anxiety problems were reported in four children by both parents and teachers, and ADHD problems were reported in three children by parents and in four children by teachers.

sec.title: Rating scales
sec.p: Parents and teachers of both the clinical and control participants completed the ASEBA where the Syndrome scales are designed to evaluate children’s behavioural and emotional functioning (Achenbach, 2010). Parents of clinical participants also completed the Parent General Behaviour Inventory 10-item bipolar scale (PGBI–10) for bipolar symptoms exhibited within the past year, each graded from 0 to 3 (Youngstrom, Frazier, Demeter, Calabrese, & Findling, 2008). Similarities are observed in questionnaire-rated symptoms between the clinical groups, with few exceptions (the BD-nonpsychosis group had significantly better scores for Academic ability than the ADHD–C and BD-psychosis groups, the BD-psychosis group was significantly more impaired than the ADHD–C group on parent-reported Internalizing problems and the ADHD–C group had fewer parent-reported bipolar symptoms (PGBI–10) than both BD groups). Questionnaire scores and other characteristics of the sample are presented in Table 1.

tr.th: B vs. AB vs. A vs. C
Bp vs. Bn vs. A vs. C

tr.td: Rating scales home (Smaller is better. PGBI–10: raw score, otherwise CBCL, inverted T-scores)
Rating scales school (Smaller is better. TRF, inverted T-scores)

fn.p: Values are in median (range) or number (percentages).

A: ADHD combined type; B: bipolar disorder; Bp: bipolar disorder with a history of psychosis; Bn: bipolar disorder with no history of psychosis; C: controls; CBCL: Child behavior Checklist; PTSD: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder; TRF: Teacher Report Form.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Kruskal–Wallis or chi square test

fn.label: b
fn.p: Bipolar symptoms last year, raw scores

fn.label: c
fn.p: Sub-scores on Anxious/depressed, Withdrawn/depressed and Somatic complaints

fn.label: d
fn.p: Sub-scores on Rule-breaking and Aggressive behaviour

fn.label: e

fn.label: f
fn.p: Mostly related to neglect/abuse

fn.label: g
fn.p: Reported from parents.

sec.title: Neuropsychological assessment
sec.p: All clinical participants completed an IQ-test: the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC–III) or for Adults (WAIS–III, from age 16) (Wechsler, 1991, 1997). In the control group, IQ was estimated from scaled scores from the WISC–III/WAIS–III Picture Completion and Similarities subtests (Egeland, Johansen, & Ueland, 2009).

sec.title: Working memory
sec.p: Working memory involves holding information in the mind while performing a mental operation (Baddeley, 1974).

sec.title: Verbal working memory
sec.p: Test: the Digit Span test (Wechsler, 1991, 1997). Task: to repeat a series of orally presented number sequences (of increasing difficulty), forwards and backwards. The backwards test is the most robust indicator of executive function. Score: number of sequences completed.

sec.title: Visuospatial working memory
sec.p: Test: Knox Cube Test (Arthur, 1947). The examiner taps four cubes in prearranged sequences of increasing difficulty. Task: to imitate the tapping pattern. Score: number of sequences completed.

sec.title: Cognitive flexibility
sec.p: Cognitive flexibility involves problem solving (goal-directed cognitive activity that arises in situations for which there is no immediately apparent resolution) and set-shifting (ability to shift cognitive strategy when needed). Test: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) performed on a personal computer (Heaton, 1981). Task: to place 128 cards one-by-one under four stimulus cards according to a shifting principle (colour, shape or number) that must be deduced from scarce feedback from the computer (correct or incorrect). Every time the participant achieves 10 ‘right’ answers in a row, the organizing principle changes without warning. The procedure continues until six categories are successfully completed or until all 128 cards have been used. Scores: problem solving ability was scored by per cent conceptual-level responses (three or more correct card placements in a row; believed to reveal insight into the correct card-sorting principle); set-shifting ability was scored by per cent perseverative errors.

sec.title: Inhibition
sec.p: Inhibition can be categorized into three interrelated processes (Barkley, 1997): inhibition of an initial response, inhibition of an ongoing response and inhibition of interfering stimuli.

sec.title: Inhibition of initial response
sec.p: Test: Children’s Checking Task (Margolis, 1972). Task: to circle numbers on the page if they differ from the numbers read on the recording. The test is designed as a measure of inattention (omissions) and response inhibition (commissions). Score: errors of commission.

sec.title: Inhibition of ongoing response
sec.p: Test: Conners’ Continuous Performance Test–II (Conners, 2000). Letters appear on the screen at unequal intervals. Task: to press the button every time a letter other than X appears. Score: errors of commission.

sec.title: Inhibition of interfering stimuli (hereafter named interference control)
sec.p: Test: Stroop Colour–Word Naming Test (Golden, 1978). Task: to avoid reading the word and instead name the ink colour in which the word is written. Score: number per 45 seconds.

sec.title: Processing speed
sec.p: Executive function may depend on efficient processing speed (Koziol, Budding, & Chidekel, 2010).

sec.title: Verbal processing speed
sec.p: Test: Stroop Word-Naming. Task: to read the colour names.

sec.title: Nonverbal processing speed
sec.p: Test: Stroop Colour-Naming. Task: to name the colours. Scores: correct answers per 45 seconds.

sec.title: Ethics
sec.p: The Regional Committee of Medical Research Ethics in Southern Norway and the Norwegian Social Science Data Service approved the study. Participants and caregivers were given verbal and written information regarding the study. Caregivers and children aged ≥12 years gave written consent and younger children gave oral consent. The study was carried out in accordance with the principles of the Helsinki Declaration.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS software for Windows version 16 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois). Two-sided alpha levels of p<0.05 were used to determine statistical significance.

Test data were analysed using generalized linear models. The generalized linear model is an extension of the linear modelling process that enables models to be fitted to data that follow probability distributions other than a normal distribution (e.g. Poisson distribution) and that allows for relaxation of the requirement for equality of variances that is required for hypothesis tests in traditional linear models. We analysed the raw scores with covariates of age and gender. Pair-wise post-hoc analyses were performed with sequential Bonferroni adjustments because we considered simple Bonferroni correction too conservative for the multiple groups in the present study (Holm, 1979).
To adjust for the indirect effect of processing speed on executive impairments, the analyses were repeated with Stroop Colour-Naming (nonverbal processing speed) included as a covariate in the model.
Stroop Colour-Naming was chosen as a measure of processing speed because it is independent of motor speed and linguistic skills.

Because most of the clinical group differences were considered illness specific, they were not entered as covariates in the neurocognitive comparisons (Table 1), but follow-up regression analyses explored the impact of mood symptoms and medication on the main findings. The effect of estimated IQ was also explored in follow-up regression analyses.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Performance on the neuropsychological tests and comparisons between the clinical and control groups are presented in Table 2 and Table 3. All clinical groups were significantly impaired on measures of cognitive flexibility, working memory, interference control and processing speed. The comorbid group was the most impaired. There were no significant differences between the BD and ADHD–C groups.

caption.p: Executive performance in bipolar disorder with and without comorbid ADHD compared with ADHD only and controls.

tr.th: B vs. BA vs. A vs. C

fn.p: Estimated means (95% confidence interval) based on raw scores with covariate age and gender.

B: bipolar disorder; A: attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder combined type; BA: B+A; C: controls; WCST: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test; CCT: Children’s Checking Task; CCPT–II: Conners’ Continuous Performance Test. *Significant after sequential Bonferroni adjustment.

caption.p: Executive performance in bipolar disorder with and without a history of psychosis, compared with ADHD and healthy controls.

tr.th: Bn vs. Bp vs. A vs. C

fn.p: Estimated means (95% confidence interval) based on raw scores with covariates age and gender. Bp: B with a history of psychosis. Bn: B with no history of psychosis.
A: ADHD. C: controls. WCST: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test. CCT: Children’s Checking Task. CCPT–II: Conners’ Continous Performance Test.
significant after Sequential Bonferroni adjustment.

sec.title: BD with and without a history of psychotic symptoms
sec.p: As shown in Table 4, the BD group was split into a BD-psychotic subgroup with a history of psychotic symptoms, and a BD-nonpsychotic subgroup without indications of previous psychotic symptoms. The BD+ADHD–C group was too small for analyses on subgroups.

caption.p: Speed adjusted executive performance in bipolar disorder with and without a history of psychosis, compared with ADHD and healthy controls.

tr.th: Bp vs. Bn vs. A vs. C

fn.p: Estimated means (95% confidence interval) based on raw scores with covariate age and gender.

Bp: bipolar disorder with a history of psychosis; Bn: bipolar disorder with no history of psychosis; C: controls; WCST: Wisconsin Card Sorting Test; CCT: Children’s Checking Task; CCPT–II: Conners’ Continuous Performance Test. Generalized linear models.
Significant after sequential Bonferroni adjustment.

sec.p: The BD-psychotic subgroup performed significantly below controls on measures of cognitive flexibility, working memory, interference control and processing speed. The BD-nonpsychotic group was significantly impaired only on the measures of processing speed.

sec.title: Indirect effect of speed
sec.p: Interference control difficulties were primarily an indirect effect of impaired processing speed in the BD-psychosis and the ADHD–C groups (Table 3). Working memory difficulties were also related to processing speed. However, visuospatial difficulties in the BD-psychosis group remained significantly impaired after adjusting for processing speed. Speed adjustments had a negligible effect on WCST impairment in the ADHD–C and BD-psychosis groups.

sec.title: Other exploratory analyses
sec.p: Removing participants with a diagnosis of BD–NOS from the sample revealed more pronounced deficits in the remaining BD–I/BD–II group, and also a significant impairment on digit span in the BD-nonpsychosis group. Otherwise, significant differences between the groups did not alter.
Mood symptoms, medication during testing and estimated IQ did not significantly affect any of the ANCOVA models.

sec.title: BD and ADHD
sec.p: We detected executive impairments in BD independently of comorbid ADHD–C and no significant differences in executive functioning between the BD and ADHD–C groups; therefore, executive differences cannot assist in their differentiation. The BD+ADHD–C group was the most impaired, indicating an additive effect of the comorbid condition, or – alternatively – that this group represents a more serious neurodevelopmental subtype of BD that is associated with comorbid ADHD (Duffy, 2010). The most impairment in the comorbid group is also reported in the, to our knowledge, only study that compared the same four groups as we have done (Rucklidge, 2006).

sec.title: BD and psychotic symptoms
sec.p: The impairments in the BD group were associated with a history of psychotic symptoms. The BD-nonpsychosis group was impaired only on a measure of processing speed. This is in line with Simonsen et al. (2011), who reported that adult BD patients with a history of psychotic episodes showed similar cognitive dysfunction to that observed in schizophrenia, whereas those with no history of psychotic symptoms were impaired only on the measure of processing speed. Our findings are also in agreement with James et al. (2011), who revealed neuropsychological and structural brain changes in paediatric BD with psychosis.

A recent meta-analysis found that youths with BD suffer from cognitive deficits that are milder than but similar to those observed in early onset schizophrenia (Nieto & Castellanos, 2011). This finding may indicate that executive deficits and psychosis in early onset BD are markers of a serious subtype of BD that is related to schizophrenia.

sec.title: Processing speed
sec.p: We also found that some aspects of executive difficulties were indirectly an effect of processing speed in both clinical groups. After adjusting for the indirect effect of processing speed, the BD-psychosis and ADHD–C groups remained significantly impaired on cognitive flexibility (WCST). Also, visuospatial difficulties in the BD-psychosis group survived processing speed adjustment. Visuospatial impairment in youths with BD has been reported by others (Dickstein et al., 2005; Lera-Miguel et al., 2011). Interestingly, a previous large-scale extended pedigree study of cognitive function in BD identified measures of processing speed and visual working memory (and declarative memory) as candidate endotypes for BD (Glahn et al., 2010), but that study did not include the WCST. In a longitudinal offspring study, Meyer et al. revealed WCST impairments only in those who later developed BD (2004).

To the best of our knowledge, no previous study has investigated the effect of processing speed on executive functions in youths with BD and ADHD–C, despite consistent reports of impaired processing speed in BD and slow reaction time in ADHD (Bidwell, Willcutt, DeFries, & Pennington, 2007; Glahn, et al., 2010). Our findings are supported by two BD studies in adults (Andersson, Barder, Hellvin, Lovdahl, & Malt, 2008; Antila, et al., 2011). The efficiency of cognitive functions depends on efficient processing speed, which normally reach mature levels of performance during the extensive myelinization and pruning that occurs during adolescence (Marsh, et al., 2008; Span, Ridderinkhof, & van der Molen, 2004). Impaired myelinization of prefrontal white matter tracts is found in both BD and ADHD (Pavuluri et al., 2009), and may explain the impaired processing speed found in both disorders. In the present study, speed impairment was the most pronounced cognitive deficit in both disorders, and some aspects of the executive deficits were speed-related. These findings may improve neurocognitive understanding and education strategies based on these, and perhaps reduce academic failure in youths with BD and ADHD–C.

sec.title: Neuropsychological profiles
sec.p: We found insignificant executive differences between the groups. The BD-psychosis group was numerically the most impaired on cognitive flexibility and interference control; however, the latter was an effect of low processing speed. The ADHD–C group was numerically the most impaired on verbal working memory and verbal processing speed. To some degree, these findings confirm those previously reported in a review of executive difficulties in paediatric BD and ADHD: deficits in set-shifting capacity, planning and interference control may be more specific to BD, while working memory difficulties may be more specific to ADHD (Walshaw et al., 2010).

Contemporary pathophysiological models assume that both psychotic symptoms as well as ADHD are associated with a dysregulation of dopaminergic activity prefrontal circuits (Swanson et al., 2007; Tost, Alam, & Meyer-Lindenberg, 2010). Thus, executive problems may be a shared phenotype of severe mental disorders.

Nonetheless, an understanding of cognitive abnormalities in youths with BD and ADHD–C can inform our understanding of the neurobiological systems that are disrupted by these disorders, and also facilitate tailored educational strategies in affected individuals.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: Strengths of the present study were that most of the BD patients were euthymic and not medicated during assessment. Despite extensive recruitment, the BD sample size was small, probably reflecting that this is a rare condition in child and adolescent age groups (Carlson, 2011). The convenient and small sample, and the controversy regarding the BD–NOS subtype, limits the generalization of our findings. In particular the difference in executive function between the very small BD subgroups needs to await replication before one can generalize the findings.

A weakness of the study is that the control group was not confirmed healthy by KSADS–PL. However, there is a risk that control groups can be ‘super groups’ that perform better than the average of children in general, increasing the risk for type 1 error. In our study, on the other hand, there is a risk for type II errors. However, our results are consistent with those of other studies of these disorders, and removal of participants with BD–NOS did not alter the pattern of our results. Reports of the negative impact of executive difficulties on academic functioning indicate a need for a greater focus on executive difficulties in early onset psychiatric disorders.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: None declared.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Anne Helseth Udal is a Chief Psychiatrist (PhD) at Department of Mental Health Sørlandet Hospital. Her research interests are phenomenological, biological and neurocognitive aspects in ADHD and Bipolar Disorders.
Bjørg Øygarden is a Neuropsycholgist at the Department of Rehabilitation Sørlandet Hospital. Her research interest is Neuropsychology.

Jens Egeland is a Professor at the Department of psychology University of Oslo and Director of research, professor i Vestfold Mental Health Care Trust. His research interests are Cognition, Learning and Cognitive Neuropsychology.

Ulrik Fredrik Malt is a Chief Psychiatrist at the Department of Neuropsychiatry and Psychosomatic Medicine, Professor at the Institute of Psychiatry Oslo University. His research interests are phenomenological, biological og neurocognitive aspects in Mood Disorders.
Hans Løvdahl is a Chief Psychiatrist at the Department of Mental Health Sørlandet Hospital. His research interests are phenomenological, biological and neurocognitive aspects in Mood disorders.
Are Hugo Pripp is a Statistician (PhD) at the Biostatistics and Epidemiology Unit, Oslo University Hospital-Rikshospitalet. His research interest is Biostatistics.

Berit Grøholt is a Professor Emeritus at the Section for Child and Adolescent Research and the Institute of Psychiatry, University of Oslo. Her research interests are Suicidality, Mood disorders, anxiety and Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Disorders.
